facts.text: Appellant was holder of permit to run stage carriage on Rewa-Singrauli route in Vindhya Pradesh (now Madhya Pradesh), due to expire on December 11, 1955.
On September 12, 1955, appellant applied for renewal of permit for further period.
Respondent Anant Prasad made representation against renewal of appellant's permit and applied for grant of permit to himself.
On December 9, 1955, State Transport Authority (STA), Vindhya Pradesh, ordered 'Renewed for three years', renewing appellant's permit; no express order on respondent's application.
Respondent appealed to Vindhya Pradesh Transport Appellate Tribunal against STA order.
Appellant contended before Tribunal that appeal was not competent; Tribunal rejected contention, cancelled appellant's permit, issued permit to respondent.
Appellant filed Misc. Civil Writ No. 27 of 1956 for writ of certiorari in Judicial Commissioners Court, Rewa, to quash Tribunal order; held appeal competent, writ dismissed on April 21, 1956.
Present appeal to Supreme Court against Judicial Commissioner's order.

legal_issues.text: Did an appeal lie to the Appellate Tribunal from the order made by the State Transport Authority renewing appellant's permit and implicitly refusing respondent's application?

petitioner_arguments.text: No appeal lay under s.64 as respondent not covered by cl.(e) or cl.(f); cannot imply refusal under cl.(a) because fresh applications cannot be considered until renewal objections disposed; ss.47,57,58 require renewal first.
Renewed permit is continuation of old; no consideration of new applications needed.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: V. C. K. Bus Service Ltd. v. Regional Transport Authority, Coimbatore

petitioner_arguments.text: Even if appeal competent under s.64(a), Tribunal cannot set aside renewal without foundation under cl.(f) as respondent not entitled to appeal under cl.(f).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.64(f); Dholpur Co-operative Transport Etc. Union Ltd. v. Appellate Authority, Rajasthan; Nadar Transport case

respondent_arguments.text: Right of appeal under s.64(a) as aggrieved by refusal to grant permit; STA order renewing appellant's implicitly refused respondent's application as only one permit available.

court_reasoning.text: Respondent aggrieved by refusal under s.64(a) as STA order granting to appellant necessarily refused respondent's; no express refusal needed; agrees with S. Gopala Reddi case.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Grant of permit to one automatically means refusal to other.

court_reasoning.text: No merit in priority argument; ss.47,57,58 do not prevent considering renewal and new applications together; s.58 requires renewal treated as new application, preference if equal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Applications heard together; STA had jurisdiction over respondent's application.

court_reasoning.text: Renewed permit not precluding new applications; VCK Bus case does not support.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Authority can consider fresh along with renewal.

court_reasoning.text: In appeal under s.64(a), Tribunal can set aside renewal/grant; cl.(f) independent, does not restrict; no foundation needed under cl.(f); disagrees with Dholpur on this point.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appeal under cl.(a) effective; sets whole order at large.

holdings.text: Appeal to Tribunal competent under s.64(a); order refusing permit implied; Tribunal could cancel renewal and grant to appellant.

precedents_cited.case_name: S. Gopala Reddi v. Regional Transport Authority, North Arcot
precedents_cited.relevance: Identical facts; grant to one implies refusal to other; appeal under s.64(a) attacks renewal.

precedents_cited.case_name: V. C. K. Bus Service Ltd. v. Regional Transport Authority, Coimbatore
precedents_cited.relevance: Renewed permit continuation of old, but does not preclude considering new applications with renewal.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dholpur Co-operative Transport Etc. Union Ltd. v. Appellate Authority, Rajasthan
precedents_cited.relevance: Disagrees that no jurisdiction to cancel grant without cl.(f) foundation in s.64(a) appeal.

precedents_cited.case_name: Nadar Transport, Tiruchirapalli v. State of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: s.64(a) and (f) for different situations; appellate power not restricted.

statutes_cited.name: Motor Vehicles Act, 1939
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs permits, appeals; s.64(a) allows appeal by aggrieved by refusal to grant; renewal applications treated as new under s.58; all heard together.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court held appeal to Tribunal was competent under s.64(a) of Motor Vehicles Act, 1939; affirmed Tribunal's cancellation of appellant's renewed permit and grant to respondent; dismissed appellant's appeal against Judicial Commissioner's dismissal of writ.
outcome.relief_granted: None to appellant; upheld grant to respondent.

key_quotes.text: "The grant of a permit to one, would automatically mean the refusal of the permit to the other."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning for implied refusal under s.64(a)

key_quotes.text: "Clause f deals with a case where an objection had been filed... Each is independent of the others."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Cl.(f) does not restrict powers in cl.(a) appeal

key_quotes.text: "The filing of the appeal by the appellant set at large the order of the Regional Transport Authority granting the renewal."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Appeal under s.64(a) allows full review including renewal
